item.description:
Current Activities

I am a PhD student in the School of Computer Science at the University of St Andrews, and member of the System Research Group. My research topic is focus on nMANET, which is an approach that intends to offer an alternative to solve the limitations of Mobile Ad-hoc Networks in emergency scenarios such as earthquakes and social riots. nMANET research intends to show whether future internet architecture such as Name Data based Networking protocol can be applied in Mobila Ad-hoc networks. To achieve this, I am designing, implementing and testing JNFD, which is the prototype of nMANET, to be functional in Andriod and Linux base mobile devices. The source code of JNFD is open source and it has been tested in real mobile devices such as MotoE, MotoG, and Samsumg Note4, and through simulators such as Mininet-Wifi.


nMANET research projec is supervised by Dr. Alexander Voss and Dr. Ishbel Duncan.

Areas of interest

One of my main interests is to be involved in backend projecs for Unix based platforms, such as minimal Debian/Ubuntu and Android, and build and deploy systems and services by utilising programming languages such as Java, C/C++, Unix Shell Scripting and Python. Additionally, I am interested to have direct contact and control of the infrastructure, such as servers and smartphones.


In daily basis, I use i3 as my main windows manager, I usually open a terminator terminal and interact most of the time through the console or through command lines for most of operations such as Vim editing, search in Internet, play on/off line music. If you are interested visit my tools for more details. I have participated in projects in areas such as robile and long distance telecommunication, cloud and data center infrastructure for mobile gaming platforms, development for post trading platfoms in stock markets, and big data infrastucture and analysis. Some personal and academic code are available in the repository link for your consideration. However, I am also interested in to be involved in areas such as: mobile big data, decentralised data distribution, social data analysis, wireless and wired networks, mobile cloud computing, embeded systems, and power saving techniques.
